body:
Is this not working today? AutoMapper checks runtime types as well,
traversing up he inheritance hierarchy. I ask because we do this sort of
thing pretty often. Why do you have to substitute for the proxy?

On Monday, November 4, 2013, athoma13 wrote:

> Hi, I would like to be able to call
> 
> Mapper.Map<Animal, AnimalDto>(animal);
> 
> Where Both Animal and AnimalDto are abstract classes AND animal is in fact
> a proxy to a NHibernate object. I would imagine this working by using
> Mappings similar to this:
> 
> Mapper.CreateMap<Animal, AnimalDto>()
> .PreMap(animalProxy => Helper.CastToEntity(animalProxy))
> .Include<Cat, CatDto>
> .Include<Dog, DogDto>
> 
> The PreMap would give me an injection point to substitute what I am
> mapping for something else (only substituting an Animal for another Animal
> in the example) But what in reality, I could be substituting a dynamic
> AnimalProxy for a 'real' Cat or Dog entity before continuing on with the
> mappings.
> 
> Of course I could solve this by calling CastToEntity on everything before
> passing it to Mapper.Map, but that gets complicated when mapping a Kennel
> that contains a list of Animals...
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/409
> .

@jbogard, it does not work properly because of inheritance.

So, he have following hierarchy:

Animal
Cat: Animal
Dog: Animal

And NHibernate will create following proxies:
AnimalProxy: Animal
CatProxy: Cat
DogProxy: Dog.

As you can see there is no inheritance between proxies.

And at the time of mapping NHibernate sometimes does not know to which
actual type the entity will be resolved. So it is an "AnimalProxy". And
when we de-proxy entity it could become to "Dog", "Cat" or "DogProxy" or
"CatProxy".

Well put Alexander,

That's exactly the problem.

And the 'Substitution' or 'PreMap' would solve this problem by being able
to Resolve the entity before applying the Mappings. The 'PreMap' step could
take a proxy, resolve it, and return a Cat or Dog so that AutoMapper
applies the Mappings from a source Cat or Dog rather than from a
AnimalProxy...

Arnaud

All I need for now is Func<TSource, TSource>...

Func<TSource, TNewSource> would mess up the fluent-interface wouldn't it?

Arnaud

type? And you need to replace that object? Perhaps you could expand on what
that CastToEntity will do?

> So what is the purpose? That NHibernate is returning something of the wrong type?

It is not a wrong type. NHibernate just does not know what actual type is behind of a proxy and C#/CIL do not support multiple inheritance

> Perhaps you could expand on what that CastToEntity will do?

I guess it will do `NHibernateUtil.Initialize(source)` or the thing which [explained here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/755903/259946) but it basically the same.

But won't that replace the source object? If I'm going from AnimalProxy to
Cat, that's a different object, no?

The reason I'm asking this is I'm not sure that this extension will solve
your problem. There's "BeforeMap" and ConstructUsing, but neither take the
source object and effectively let you "replace" it.

notifications@github.com> wrote:

> It is not a wrong type NHibernate just does not know what type would be
> resolved as a proxy.
> 
> Perhaps you could expand on what that CastToEntity will do?
> 
> I guess it will do NHibernateUtil.Initialize(source)
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/409#issuecomment-27808025
> .

Well, you can argue that NHibernate returns the 'wrong' type with the
people who wrote it. I will sit on the fence about that one.

Here is what CastToEntity does...

public T CastToEntity<T>(object o)
{
        var proxy = source as NHibernate.Proxy.INHibernateProxy;
        if (proxy != null) return
(T)proxy.HibernateLazyInitializer.GetImplementation();
        return source;
}

Hello,

I saw this post and as I encounter the same issue with NH proxy I'm coming to see if someone got update on it ? Actually I had to build my own Value Injecter based on : http://valueinjecter.codeplex.com/ to make it work.

However for non-proxy situations its around 10x times slower than AutoMapper...(rely on reflection)

Many Thanks.
I can build something but I need a way to verify it. If you can give me a bit of code that shows the issue that allows me to reproduce it, that would help.
Ok, let me see what I can do. What configuration are you using VS 12 or 13 is fine for you ?

Either works. I'm mainly in VS 2013, but I have both.

On Thu, Jan 30, 2014 at 9:36 AM, lejige notifications@github.com wrote:

> Ok, let me see what I can do. What configuration are you using VS 12 or 13
> is fine for you ?
